Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, you’re leading the ceremony tonight. It means a lot to your father.” My family had always counted on me to uphold our traditions, especially during important rituals. I could already picture my relatives gathering, waiting for me to guide the prayers, my father’s proud smile, my mother’s hopeful eyes. But just as I set the phone down, a Slack notification popped up—urgent, all caps: “PRODUCTION OUTAGE. Users locked out. Need you ASAP.” My heart pounded. The bug was in my code, and the whole team was scrambling. Customers were angry, managers were watching, and I was the only one who could fix it quickly. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of my family’s expectations pressing on one side, the responsibility to my team and users on the other. My hands trembled as I hovered between replying to my mother and opening my laptop, torn by the fear of letting someone down no matter what I chose.
